ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course provides archeological case studies from various regions across the world. I develop insights about the archeological methodologies used by researchers to uncover evidence about urban ancient cities and their hinterlands. As an undergrad, I also learn how to write a good grant proposal and conduct relevant literature reviews on the course's topic.

I learned about various modes of urbanism present in pre-industrial societies around the world and different scholarly approaches to the concept of urbanism. Through the assignments, we also practised skills such as leading a seminar discussion, synthesizing different schools of thought, and writing and presenting research proposals.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course's instructors and TF provide very thorough feedback on the major assignments. The course also dedicated an entire week of readings and discussions to materials related to the history of racial oppression, which is something I really appreciated, especially in light of how academic research can shed light on social issues. The course could be improved by breaking the 3 hours once a week schedule into 2 meet ups, since the long discussions tend to lose momentum at the end.

I was really appreciative of the fact that the readings each week came from various civilizations and were organized around themes under urbanism, rather than focusing on individual societies each week, meaning that we were able to conduct comparative studies of urban societal features such as consumption patterns and urban structure. The assignments were also well-designed and mindful of the fact that students have focused on different areas in the world, as they had a great degree of flexibility in terms of content and how they should be completed.
My only criticism is that sometimes if I ask a question about an area outside of the instructors' expertise, their answers leave me with something to be desired and I often have to seek help from other professors outside the class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would highly recommend it to any students with an interest in archeology and urban studies. The course's discussions cover methodologies and results that are most prominent in the field.

Absolutely. The class was extremely interesting and I likely would have taken it even if it did not count towards my major. I found the course to be well-organized and up-to-date, as many of the readings came from very recent publications. Both professors are extremely experienced and passionate about the subject and do a really good job explaining and clarifying the material. If you take this class, you will likely be among passionate peers, many of whom are likely graduate students, and can encounter new techniques for conducting archaeological analysis.
